title: Moses' Commission
shortSummary: Exodus chapter 4 details God's commissioning of Moses to lead Israel out of Egypt, including the provision of miraculous signs to authenticate his calling. Despite Moses' objections and insecurities, God assures him of His presence and appoints Aaron as his spokesman. The chapter ends with Moses returning to Egypt and the people's initial belief in God's intervention.

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The chosen deliverer of Israel who initially doubts his ability but is commissioned by God to confront Pharaoh and lead the Israelites out of Egypt.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: Moses' brother and spokesman, appointed by God to assist Moses by speaking on his behalf to the people and Pharaoh.

keyCharacters.name: Jethro
keyCharacters.description: Moses' father-in-law who grants Moses permission to return to Egypt to fulfill God's command.

keyCharacters.name: Zipporah
keyCharacters.description: Moses' wife who performs a critical act of circumcision on their son to avert God's judgment on Moses during their journey.

definitions.definition: A staff or stick used as a symbol of authority and power; in this chapter, it becomes a sign of God's miraculous power.
Describes a condition resembling leprosy, a skin disease; here used as a sign to demonstrate God's power to Moses.
A covenantal physical sign commanded by God, involving the removal of the foreskin of a male child, symbolizing the covenant between God and His people.
One who speaks on behalf of another; Aaron is appointed to be Moses' spokesman because of Moses' difficulty with speech.

outline.heading: Moses' Doubt and God's Signs
outline.description: Moses expresses fear that the Israelites will not believe God's call, so God provides three miraculous signs involving the rod, leprous hand, and water turning to blood to authenticate Moses' mission.

outline.heading: Moses' Objection and God's Assurance
outline.description: Moses protests his lack of eloquence, but God reassures him of divine guidance and appoints Aaron as his spokesman to aid in communicating God's message.

outline.heading: Preparation to Return to Egypt
outline.description: Moses seeks and receives permission from Jethro to return to Egypt, taking his family and the rod of God, as God commands him to begin the deliverance of Israel.

outline.heading: God's Warning and Zipporah's Intervention
outline.description: God warns Moses that Pharaoh's heart will be hardened, and on the journey, God seeks to kill Moses until Zipporah circumcises their son, averting the threat and fulfilling the covenant sign.

outline.heading: Moses and Aaron Reunite and Present the Signs
outline.description: Aaron meets Moses, they inform the elders of Israel of God's message and perform the signs, resulting in the people's belief and worship of God.

application: Trust God’s provision and power even when you feel inadequate or fearful in fulfilling His calling.
Obedience to God may require difficult steps, including confronting opposition and personal sacrifice.
Rely on God’s appointed helpers and community support when facing challenges in ministry or service.
Remember that God’s promises and presence are sure, even when circumstances seem discouraging or hostile.

keyVerses.text: Now therefore go, and I will be with thy mouth, and teach thee what thou shalt say.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God's promise to empower and guide Moses, assuring believers that God equips those He calls.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD said unto Moses, When thou goest to return into Egypt, see that thou do all those wonders before Pharaoh, which I have put in thine hand: but I will harden his heart, that he shall not let the people go.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God's sovereign control over Pharaoh's heart and the unfolding of His redemptive plan.

keyVerses.text: And the people believed: and when they heard that the LORD had visited the children of Israel, and that he had looked upon their affliction, then they bowed their heads and worshipped.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows the response of faith and worship when God's deliverance becomes evident to His people.
